And him presenteth with his doghter dere.
Ye been our lord, doth with your owne thing
The more trewe, if that it were possible
For° he a povre womman wedded hadde
And am your trewe wif, it is no drede
And of your newe wif, God of his grace
But sooth is seid, algate I finde it trewe—
Love is noght old as whan that it is newe.
Remembre yow, min owne lord so dere
For out of doute this olde povre man
No tendre mouth, non herte delicaat
And to hir housbonde ever meke and stable.
As womman can, ne can ben half so trewe
Was couth° eek, that a newe markisesse
Than is Grisild, and more tendre of age
Deliting ever in rumbel° that is newe
Ay ful of clapping,° dere ynogh a jane;°
Thus seiden sadde folk° in that citee
To han a newe lady of hir toun.
That in so povre array was for to see
As coude a povre° fostred creature.”
Now knowe I, dere wif, thy stedfastnesse,”
I wol with lusty° herte fresshe and grene
Sin° ye be stronge as is a greet camaille;°
And waike° been the oxen in my plough.
And swoor his ooth, as he was trewe knight
Nat fully quike,° ne fully dede they were
Nat fully quike,° ne fully dede they were
She gadereth floures, party° white and rede
She gadereth floures, party° white and rede
And soothly,° leve brother, this is al.
That many a trewe man hath doon mescheef,°
So muche sorwe had never creature
So feble eek were his spirits, and so lowe
And cladde him as a povre laborer
Welcome be thou, faire fresshe May
Welcome be thou, faire fresshe May
A longe time; and after he up sterte.
And seide: “Arcite, false traitour wikke,°
That frothen° white as foom for ire wood.°
Youre owne mouth, by your confessioun
And sawe hir blody woundes wide and sore;
And yet they wenen° for to been ful wise
Can° hem therfor as muche thank as me;
And eek of Emelie, my suster dere.
Al be° ye never so jelous, ne so wrothe.
As I shal even° juge been and trewe.
With wawes° grene, and brighte as any glas.°
His shuldres brode, his armes rounde and longe.
With nailes yelwe and brighte as any gold
Twenty and mo, as grete as any steer
Armed ful wel with hertes sterne and stoute.
Couched with perles white and rounde and grete.
Couched with perles white and rounde and grete.
Ne renoun° in this cas, ne veine glorie
And if ye wol nat so, my lady swete
Yif me my love, thou blisful lady dere.”
Quene of the regne of Pluto derk and lowe
Chaste goddesse, wel wostow° that I
That al hir hote love, and hir desir
But sodeinly she saugh a sighte queinte,°
Of faire yonge fresshe Venus free,°
Of faire yonge fresshe Venus free,°
Out goon the swerdes as the silver brighte.
I wol be trewe juge, and no partie.°
And Palamon, that was his cosin dere;
That dwelled in his herte sik° and sore
Of olde folk, and folk of tendre yeres
Upon thise stedes, that weren grete and white
Upon thise stedes, that weren grete and white
With slakke pas,° and eyen rede and wete
That gentil Palamon, your owne knight
And, though° he were a povre bacheler,°
Thou ferse° god of armes, Mars the rede
Whan Theseus, with werres longe and grete
That everich other slough,° so wer they wrothe.°
Were dede, and slaine proud Campaneus
For she to him so lowly was and trewe
And saw another lady, proud and newe
And thus endureth, til that she was so mate°
His hert was elleswhere, newe and grene
But lest that he wer proude, she held him lowe;
Sith it availeth not for to ben trewe;
Whiche is the wey to doon° yow to be trewe?
For to be trewe, and mercy me to preye.°
¶And ye maistresses° in your olde lif,°
Bothe of hir beautee and hir bountee° wide;
Toward a temple, with hir moder dere
And yaf° him yiftes preciouse and dere.
“To yow, my lord, sire Apius so dere,°
Sheweth° your povre servant Claudius
¶“O mercy, dere fader,” quod this maide
And seide, “Gode fader, shal I die?
“No, certes, dere doghter min,” quod he.
Of° wikked lif, though it so privee° be
That hem hath holpen whan that they were seke
The chambres and the stables weren wide
And of his port as meke as is a maide
His hors were goode but he was nat gay
Al ful of fresshe floures white and rede
Short was his gown with sleves longe and wide
Harneised wel and sharpe as point of spere
And al was conscience and tendre herte
For unto a poure ordre for to yive
For many a man so harde is of his herte
To make his English swete upon his tonge
He semed swich his wordes weren so wise
For he was Epicurus owne sone
Poinaunt and sharpe and redy al his gere
Ful fresh and newe hir gere apiked was
Hir frendshipe nas nat newe to biginne
Ful streite yteid and shoos ful moiste and newe
And was a povre Parson of a toun
A trewe swinkere and a good was he
For Cristes sake for every povre wight
His nosethirles blake were and wide
For to be wise in byinge of vitaille
Ful longe were his legges and ful lene
But smothe it heng as dooth a strike of flex
As smothe it was as it were late yshave
A povre person dwelling upon lond
Our counseil was nat longe for to seche
Of chapmen° riche, and therto sadde and trewe,°
Of chapmen° riche, and therto sadde and trewe,°
Her chaffar° was so thrifty° and so newe,°
And al this vois° was soth,° as God is trewe
The deeth; but mennes wittes been so dulle
And in encrees of Cristes lawe dere
Housbondes been alle gode, and han ben yore,°
Nas° herd swich tendre weping for pitee
Allas! we ben to lewed° or to slowe.
To shippe is brought this woful faire maide
For though his wif be cristned never so white
As any moder mighte hir doghter dere
In general, ye! bothe yonge and olde.
In general, ye! bothe yonge and olde.
O emperoures yonge doghter dere
And Custance hath so longe sojourned there
With whiche men seen, after that they ben blinde.
Fro false blame, and thou, merciful maide,°
Now faire Custance, that is so humble and meke
Thy face is turned in a newe array!°
Wepen bothe yonge and olde in al that place
Wepen bothe yonge and olde in al that place
In him triste° I, and in his moder dere
Thou glorie of wommanhede, thou faire may,°
Thou haven° of refut,° brighte sterre° of day
O mercy, dere constable!” quod she;
Habundantly for hir, ful longe space
And longe time dwelled she in that place
“Fader,” quod she, “your yonge child Custance
Now, Gode fader, mercy I yow crie
With his Custance, his holy wif so swete
Not longe time to endure
That clerkes° had, in olde time
Hom, for it was a longe terme.
¶“A mercy, swete ladi dere!”
¶“A mercy, swete ladi dere!”
And but° thou wilt° this, ladi swete
Amid the valey, wonder depe.
¶This cave was also as derke
For certes, swete, I am but dede;
It were to longe for to dwelle;
Me met° so inly° swete a swevene,°
Was never herd so swete a steven,°
Was nowher herd yet half so swete
With many gladde° gilde° stremes;
And eek the welken° was so faire
Blew, bright, clere was the aire
Whether it were clere or hors° of soune.
Fro al the hounds a prive° way.
And leide al smothe° doun his heres.°
Ful thikke of gras, ful softe and swete
With floures fel,° faire under fete
And his spirites wexen dede;°
Doun to his hert, to make him warme—
Him thought his sorwes were so smerte°
Were for his sorwes never so wrothe.°
He saide, “I prey thee, be not wrothe
He made it nouther tough ne queinte°
That semeth ful seke° under your side.”
“Graunt mercy, goode frend,” quod he
My lif, my lustes° be me loothe
For al welfare and I be wroothe.°
Alway deyinge, and be not dede
That is a false flatering beste;
That is ay fals, and semeth wele
I hold that wish nat worthe a stre!°
Was false whiche° a fool she was!
To love hooly with goode entente
And worship° to my lady dere.
¶“And this was longe, and many a yere
As a white walle or a table;
Forwhy° I toke it of so yonge age
Al° were to me yliche° goode
That as the sommers sonne brighte
Soth to seyne, it was not rede
Debonair, goode, glade, and sadde,°
Debonair, goode, glade, and sadde,°
Debonair, goode, glade, and sadde,°
Simple, of good mochel,° noght to wide;
She nas to sobre° ne to glad;
But goode folk, over al other
And eek° my spirits be so dulle
So grete a thing for to devise.°
And moustre;° for, be it never so derke
So swete a sowninge facounde,°
Was founde as trewe as any bonde,°
It was whit, smooth, streght, and pure flatte
Semed a rounde toure of ivoire,°
Of good gretnesse,° and noght to grete.
¶“And goode faire White she hete,°
¶“And goode faire White she hete,°
That was my lady name righte.
She was bothe faire and brighte,°
She was bothe faire and brighte,°
Right faire shuldres, and body longe°
Right so ferd° my lady dere;
And seye, “Sir, be now right ware°
She was as good, and nothing like
Algate° she was as trewe as she.
I was right yonge, soth to say
To love, it was a grete emprise.°
Were my sorwes never so smerte.°
Noght longe time, leve° hit wel.
My lady, that is so faire and bright!”—
I am adred she wol be wrothe;
So moche beaute, trewely
I most have tolde hir or be dede.
Ful ofte I wex both pale and rede;°
That she wold be my lady swete;
Ever to be stedfast and trewe
For evermore, min herte swete!
¶“Therwith she was alway so trewe,°
Our joy was ever yliche newe;°
Ylich they were both glad and wrothe;°
¶Therwith he waxe° as dede as stoon
Hir freendes soules, as wel olde as yonge
Hir freendes soules, as wel olde as yonge
A dagon° of your blanket,° leve° dame
Our suster dere, lo! here I write your name;
¶“Pees,” quod our Host, “for Cristes moder dere;
But of your grete goodness, by your leve
Thise curatz° been ful necligent and slowe
Suffisen° us, though they be nat ful gode.
But° they be sobre that° for the peple preye
‘Blessed be they that povre° in spirit been.’
But we that humble been and chast and pore
Of charitable and chaste bisy freres
And for to builden Cristes owne chirche.
Your wif, that is so meke and pacient.
I coude of ire sey so muche sorwe
But if° it be unto a poure man.
To a poure man men sholde hise vices telle
¶“Now Thomas, leve brother, lef° thin ire;°
That in this world is noon so poure° a page,°
O nice° proude cherl, I shrewe° his face!
Lo, sires,” quod the lord, “with harde grace,°
And Jankin hath ywonne a newe goune.—
Whan she forgoth hir owene swete herte?
No wonder is, for it is to yow newe
But wolde never God but if as trewe
Your owene aboven every creature.
And wol do fain that is him leef and dere;
And in his throwes frenetik and madde
“Wher is min owene lady lief and dere
Shal been your fresshe wommanliche face
My swerd, min helm, and, leve brother dere
My swerd, min helm, and, leve brother dere
For wel thow wost, my leve brother dere
This Troilus answerde, “O brother dere
“But sin of fine force I moot arise
Welcome, ywis, min owene lady dere.”
The lettres eek, that she of olde time
And seide, “Leve brother Pandarus
And to Pandare, his owene brother dere
So pitously and with so dede an hewe
Me caughte first my righte lady dere.
‘Now goode swete, love me wel, I preye.’
Herde I min alderlevest lady dere
With softe vois he, of his lady dere
I shal be glad, if al the world be trewe!
Whan hennes rood my righte lady dere
For wise folk in bokes it expresse
She sobre was, eek simple, and wis withal
Yong, fresshe, strong, and hardy as lioun;
Trewe as steel in ech condicioun;
This Diomede, as fresshe as braunche in May
And after this, withouten longe lette
“What wene ye your wise fader wolde
“What wol ye more, lufsom lady dere?
Inwith hir fadres faire brighte tente.
That she him yaf the faire baye stede
To Diomede algate I wol be trewe.
Almost, ywis, al newe was my care.
Er that the mone, O dere herte swete!
So were his throwes sharpe and wonder stronge.
Which that men clepeth wode Jalousie
Priam ful ofte, and eek his moder dere
That in a forest faste he welk to wepe
The blisful goddes, through hir grete might
What newe lust, what beaute, what science
What wratthe of juste cause have ye to me?
I fele now so sharpe a newe peine
I fele now so sharpe a newe peine
And to Criseyde, his owene lady dere
As ye wel knowe how longe time agoon
“For which to yow, with dredful herte trewe
And over al this, that ye, my lady dere
Foryeve it me, min owene swete herte.
As wisly as in al I am yow trewe.
“Ywis, min owene dere herte trewe
“Ywis, min owene dere herte trewe
And fareth wel, goodly faire fresshe may
And fareth wel, goodly faire fresshe may
She gan first smile, and seide, “O brother dere
And ofte time he was in purpos grete
To been unknowen of folk that weren wise
I hertelees, I sike, I in distresse;
To feffe with your newe love,” quod he
How trewe is now thy nece, bright Criseyde!
But trewely, Criseyde, swete may
Through false folk; God yeve hem sorwe, amen!
That with hir grete wit and subtiltee
And sin he best to love is, and most meke
Lo here, the forme of olde clerkes speche

context: What though° thin hors be bothe foule° and lene
I dar not seyn, his strokes° been so sore
And how his auncestre, African so dere
To comen swiftly to that place dere,°
And likerous° folk, after that they be dede
Citherea! thou blisful lady swete
But natheles, although that thou be dulle
And colde welle-stremes, nothing dede,°
And upon pilers grete of jasper° longe°
Faire of hemself,° and somme of hem were gay;°
Of newe flaume; and wel aspied I thenne
And in a privee corner, in disporte,°
And greye, I mene the goshauk, that doth pine°
The wedded turtel,° with hir herte trewe;°
The wise and worthy, secree,° trewe as stel
Right as the fresshe, rede rose newe
Right as the fresshe, rede rose newe
Forth with his make, or with his lady dere;
And trewe in al that herte may bethinke.”
The turtel trewe, and gunne hir to hem calle
Thy kind is of so lowe a wrechednesse
A yeer is not so longe to endure
Of yonge folk, that haunteden° folie
Hir othes° been so grete and so dampnable
Fetis° and smale, and yonge fruitesteres,°
¶Now wol I speke of othes false and grete
And false swering is yet more reprevable.°
Of heighe Goddes hestes° honurable
Ther cam a privee° theef, men clepeth° Deeth
An old man and a povre° with hem mette.
As longe time as° it is Goddes wille.
And seye, ‘Leve° moder,° leet me in!
That in my chambre longe time hath be
To sleen us yonge folk, thou false theef!”°
To sleen us yonge folk, thou false theef!”°
For that° the florins been so faire and brighte
For that° the florins been so faire and brighte
And for our owene tresor doon us honge.°
And pleye at dees right at our owene wille.”
The beautee of thise florins newe and brighte.
As faire as any man in Engelond
And ye, sir Host, that been to me so dere
With buttoks brode and brestes rounde and hie
¶Than were ther yonge povre scolers two
I is as ille a miller as ar ye.”°
But specially, I pray thee, hoste dere
And seide, “Far wel, Malin, swete wight!°
“Now dere lemman,”° quod she, “go, far wel!
And, goode lemman, God thee save and kepe!”°
¶“Ye, false harlot,”° quod the millere, “hast?
A! false traitour! false clerk!” quod he
Save al this compaignie grete and smale!
¶A povre widwe, somdel° stape° in age
Was cleped° faire damisel° Pertelote.
In swete accord,° “My lief° is faren° in londe.”°
To han housbondes hardy,° wise, and free,°
Of youre rede colera,° pardee
Now help me, dere brother, er I die;
Bihold my blody woundes, depe and wide!
And truste wel his dreem he fond° ful trewe;
¶“O blisful God, that art so just and trewe!
¶“And therfor, faire Pertelot so dere
This storie is also° trewe, I undertake,°
False dissimilour,° O Greek Sinon
Wommennes counseils been ful ofte colde;°
¶O Gaufred,° dere maister soverain,°
And eek for me preyeth to God so dere
As though I were hir owne brother dere.
As though I were hir owne brother dere.
Kepte hir estat, and bothe of yonge and olde
Kepte hir estat, and bothe of yonge and olde
After hir cours, ay whil that they were wrothe.
With newe grene, of lusty Ver the prime
And swote smellen floures white and rede
O verrey foles! nice and blinde be ye;
At which the god of love gan loken rowe
So ferde it by this fers and proude knight;
Ye wise, proude, and worthy folkes alle
Ye wise, proude, and worthy folkes alle
Of hir his fixe and depe impressioun:
Yelt bittre fruit, though swete seed be sowe.
Yelt bittre fruit, though swete seed be sowe.
O quike deeth, O swete harm so queinte
Bicome hir man, as to my lady dere.”
O mercy, dere herte, and help me from
I have, and shal, for trewe or fals report
As I best can, gon sithen longe while.
What! many a man hath love ful dere ybought
I be thy bote, or that it be ful longe
Lord, he was glad, and seide, “Freend so dere
The rose waxeth swote and smothe and softe;

For this have I herd seide of wise ylered
